title: How to Make a TV Antenna with a Potato

steps.headline: Purchase a Potato.
steps.description: Any variety will work, but choose medium or large-sized one. Wash it to remove any dirt and dry thoroughly before using.

steps.headline: Choose an appropriate length of aerial lead (the cable that attaches the TV to the antenna or, in this case, potato).
steps.description: Between 3' and 6' should be more than enough.

steps.headline: Attach the aerial lead to the Potato.
steps.description: The pin inside the tip of the lead is the only part that should be pressed into the Potato. Take care not to break or bend the tip. (For a coaxial TV cable, only the inside pin needs to go into the potato. The metal casing should be pressed into the skin to help secure it.)

steps.headline: Use a length of electrical tape to secure the lead to the potato so it does not become dislodged.
Plug the other end of the aerial lead into the back of your television.

tyn: A length of common coaxial cable
A digital TV or analog TV with a digital converter box.
text: Purchase a Potato. Any variety will work, but choose medium or large-sized one. Wash it to remove any dirt and dry thoroughly before using. Choose an appropriate length of aerial lead (the cable that attaches the TV to the antenna or, in this case, potato). Between 3' and 6' should be more than enough. Attach the aerial lead to the Potato. The pin inside the tip of the lead is the only part that should be pressed into the Potato. Take care not to break or bend the tip. (For a coaxial TV cable, only the inside pin needs to go into the potato. The metal casing should be pressed into the skin to help secure it.) Use a length of electrical tape to secure the lead to the potato so it does not become dislodged.  Plug the other end of the aerial lead into the back of your television.
sentences: Any variety will work, but choose medium or large-sized one.
Wash it to remove any dirt and dry thoroughly before using.
Choose an appropriate length of aerial lead (the cable that attaches the TV to the antenna or, in this case, potato).
Between 3' and 6' should be more than enough.
Attach the aerial lead to the Potato.
The pin inside the tip of the lead is the only part that should be pressed into the Potato.
Take care not to break or bend the tip.
(For a coaxial TV cable, only the inside pin needs to go into the potato.
The metal casing should be pressed into the skin to help secure it.)
Use a length of electrical tape to secure the lead to the potato so it does not become dislodged.
Plug the other end of the aerial lead into the back of your television.
